item.title: A DIY Guide to Applying for Spain's Non-Lucrative Visa: Materials Checklist and Form Guidance
item.description:
Why Choose the Spanish Non-Lucrative Visa? Core Advantages: 1. Extremely Low Application Threshold The overall difficulty is comparable to an individual applying for a standard tourist visa. You only need to provide stable financial proof demonstrating that the applicant and their family can afford to live in Spain long-term without working. 2. Relatively Short Approval Period You can typically get a result within 1‚Äì3 months after submitting a complete application, which is more efficient than other long-term European residency programs. 3. Extremely Low DIY Cost The entire process can be handled by yourself, achieving virtually "zero agency fees." You only need to cover necessary costs like translation and notarization, avoiding exorbitant fees from agencies. 4. High-Quality Social Environment Spain is a developed European country with a comprehensive social security system: - Universal free healthcare - Free public education (university tuition is extremely low) - Free public transportation for specific groups in some cities - Social stability and a pace of life suitable for long-term family residence 5. Quickly Obtain a Second Identity Upon arrival in Spain, you can apply for a NIE (Foreigner’s Identity Number), which has a wide range of uses: - Opening a bank account - Booking flights and checking into hotels - Registering a company, signing contracts - Functionally very similar to an EU ID card (with some exceptions for benefits) — ## Rational Advice on the Investor Visa It is strongly advised not to blindly opt for the former ‚Ç¨500,000 Investor Visa (this policy has been canceled). Many Chinese applicants, unfamiliar with the local market, were misled by agents into buying overpriced properties: - A property quoted at ‚Ç¨500,000 by an agent might have a real market value of only ‚Ç¨200,000. - In Spain, properties with "tens of thousands of square meters of land + a thousand square meters of building" are widely available for under ‚Ç¨400,000. A more prudent path is: > First, land in Spain with a non-lucrative visa ‚Üí familiarize yourself with the market before considering buying property ‚Üí switch to an investor-type residency if needed. To avoid pitfalls when buying property, you can refer to: A Complete Guide to Buying a Second-Hand Home in Spain — ## Costs and Long-Term Planning - Total costs for translation, notarization, travel, etc.: A few thousand RMB - Maximum time allowed out of the country within 5 years: 10 months - Must reside in Spain for no less than 183 days in a single year - After 5 years: Can apply for Spanish or EU permanent residency - After obtaining permanent residency: Entering the country once a year is sufficient - After 10 years + passing a basic Spanish language test: Can apply for Spanish citizenship Official policy explanation (Spanish Ministry of Foreign Affairs): https://www.exteriores.gob.es/Consulados/pekin/zh/ServiciosConsulares/Paginas/Consular/Visado-de-residencia-no-lucrativa.aspx > Note: The above is the general legal framework. Individual consulates may have slight variations in their actual review process. — ## Choosing the Right Consulate for Submission The main applicant must choose the consulate based on their place of household registration (hukou); those already overseas can apply at the local Spanish consulate: - Consulate in Chengdu (newly established in 2023): Sichuan Province - Consulate General in Shanghai: Shanghai, Anhui, Jiangsu, Jiangxi, Zhejiang - Consulate General in Guangzhou: Fujian, Guangdong, Guizhou, Hainan, Hunan, Yunnan, Guangxi - Consulate General in Beijing: Covers the widest range, including many northern and western provinces and cities > Experience: The Beijing consular district has relatively simpler requirements, while the Shanghai district is the strictest with materials. Please use Spanish or English for inquiries: - Beijing: cog.pekin@maec.es - Guangzhou: cog.canton@maec.es - Hong Kong: cog.hongkong@maec.es - Shanghai: Cg.Shanghai@maec.es — ## Practical Tips Driver’s License Issue - The Spanish driving test is extremely difficult, and Chinese licenses cannot be exchanged for Spanish ones. - An Ecuadorian driver’s license can be exchanged for a Spanish one. - Recommendation: First, obtain an exchangeable license ‚Üí then enter Spain. Translation and Notarization - All documents must be translated into Spanish. - You can get translation + notarization + Hague apostille done on Taobao. - The criminal record check can be processed online. — ## Financial Requirements (Key) The financial standard is based on the IPREM: - Initial application: Main applicant 4 times the IPREM - For each additional family member: +1 time the IPREM - Renewal: Main applicant 8 times the IPREM, family members +2 times - 2025 IPREM: ‚Ç¨7,200 > Proof of funds from either domestic or foreign banks is acceptable. — ## Form Downloads - National Visa Application Form (Chinese version) https://www.exteriores.gob.es/Consulados/canton/es/ServiciosConsulares/Documents/nacional-es-cn.pdf

> If you don’t know how to fill them out, you can ask a Spanish translator for help. — ## Main Applicant’s Materials 1. Full copy of new passport (including blank pages) 2. Full copy of old passport(s) 3. Full copy of household registration book (Hukou) + translation 4. Criminal record certificate (translation + notarization + Hague apostille) 5. item.title: A Comprehensive Comparison of Basic Education in Spain: The Truth Chinese Parents Should Know
item.description:
Spain has a system of free and compulsory education for ages 6 to 16, covering 6 years of primary school and 4 years of secondary school.

üìö School Hours and Tuition Differences

  • Spanish Public Schools: School hours are from 9:00 AM to 2:00 PM, with 4 classes per day. Education is free.
  • Spanish Private and International Schools: School hours are typically from 9:00 AM to 4:00 PM, with 6 classes per day.
    • The median tuition for private schools is approximately ‚Ç¨6,000/year (about 50,000 RMB).
    • International schools cost around ‚Ç¨8,000/year (about 70,000 RMB).
    • Costs vary significantly by grade level, region, and school, with differences of up to 1-2 times the median.

üè´ Teaching Staff and Pedagogical Features

  • Teacher absenteeism is relatively high in Spain. A doctor’s note for sick leave is legally binding, and paid sick leave can be granted over the phone.
  • Primary schools generally use a “generalist” system, where a single teacher teaches multiple subjects like English, math, humanities, science, art, and physical education, which may limit subject-specific expertise.
  • Subject-specific teaching only begins in secondary school.
  • The saying “the gym teacher taught my math” is not a joke in Spain but a result of the generalist system in primary schools.
  • Exam scores are not ranked.

üàØ Language of Instruction and Multilingual Environment

  • International schools primarily use English for instruction.
  • Private and public schools mainly use Spanish.
  • Autonomous communities like Valencia and Catalonia require students to learn the local regional language.
  • In secondary school, a second foreign language such as French or German is added, making the multilingual workload demanding.

üìñ Workload and Holiday Schedule

  • There is less homework.
  • The academic year is divided into three terms, with a total of about 160‚Äì180 instructional days.
  • Holidays are long.

üá®üá≥ Comparison with Basic Education in China

  • Public Schools: School hours are from 8:00 AM to 4:00 PM, with 6‚Äì8 classes per day. Education is free, with some regions offering after-school programs.
  • Private/International Schools: 8:00 AM to 5:30 PM, with evening self-study sessions starting in middle school, which do not exist in Spain.
    • Private: Approx. 60,000 RMB/year
    • International: Approx. 180,000 RMB/year
  • The academic year is divided into two semesters, with over 190 instructional days.

üèüÔ∏è Disparity in Campus Facilities

  • International schools in China often have campuses exceeding 100 acres, featuring heated swimming pools, theaters, multimedia libraries, maker labs, Olympic-standard stadiums, and even equestrian centers, golf courses, and drone and robotics labs.
  • In contrast, Spanish schools are modest and compact, with simpler facilities.

üìò Curriculum and Difficulty
